Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. THE MURAL ROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: THURSDAY, 9:45 P.M. Bonnie is holding a champagne bottle, and a lot of other staffers are gathered around a T.V. listening to Mendoza's confirmation vote.

Dialogues.Line: Congratulations everybody. Congratulations. Line up. Only one drink per person. Who's driving? People come to her with glasses. Crystal. Toby walks in.
Put it down! Put it down! Put it down!

Put it down. Everyone in this room let me have your attention, please. The law of our land mandates that Presidential appointees be confirmed by a majority of the Senate. A majority being half plus one for a total of what, Ginger?
51 yea votes is what we see on the screen before a drop of wine is swallowed! Because there's a little thing called what, Bonnie?

'Tempting fate' is what it's called. [starts collecting champagne glasses from everyone] In the three months this man has been on my radar screen, I have aged 48 years. This is my day of jubilee and I will not have it screwed up by what, Bonnie?
By tempting fate! These things take patience. These things take skill. These things take luck. In the 15 months we've been in office, what kind of luck have we had, Ginger?
We've had very bad luck. [beat] Where's Josh?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. JOSH'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Donna is rushing into his office.

Dialogues.Line: We got to go. They're already 19 yea votes. Donna gets to his office. Josh is standing and holding up a note.
What's this message about I've got to talk to Mandy about a banana bar? Is that what this says?
[walks around and shows her the note] That's a 'd'?
All right, you know what would be helpful? If you could just show me where one word ends and the next one begins.
She wants to talk to me about a panda bear? They walk out into JOSH'S BULLPEN AREA.
You're sure you got the message right?
Have I ever gotten a message wrong?
Then maybe the benefit of the doubt might not be monumentally out of line.
A panda's what I think it is, right?
Little Australian thing, eats bark off a koala tree?
That's a koala bear I believe you're describing.
How can you not know the difference between a panda bear and a koala bear? They go into the NORTHWEST LOBBY. They stop because a photographer is taking a picture of someone.
You know, for someone who hasn't quite mastered the alphabet... Mallory enters the White House and walks up to them.
Josh! Josh and Donna start walking again.
Your penmanship is illegible. Hey, Mal.
He's going to be watching the Mendoza vote.
Yeah. They cut the corner into a HALLWAY.
You think you know a guy...
You don't know what I'm talking about, do you?
Okay. Josh, Donna and Mallory walk into THE MURAL ROOM. Toby is tense watching T.V. The staffers are sitting around. No longer in the party mood, just in wait.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Leo is on the phone. Margaret taps on the door.

Dialogues.Line: [into phone] I can't believe you're talking like this.
[into phone] It's a book jacket, Sydney. It's a dust cover.
[into phone] We're really going to make a federal case out of a book jacket? I mean we're literally going to make a federal case out of this?

[still into phone] Sydney, I'm going to bring him up here and talk to him, but I got to say... we're about a minute and a half from closing what wasn't the easiest confirmation process in American history, so you'll understand if I'm not giddy as a schoolgirl about the thought of running once again into the warm embrace of the Senate Judiciary Committee.
Goodbye. Leo hangs up. He walks out with Margaret into the HALLWAY.
An appointment to a Justice post favors reparations to African-Americans.
Capturing their ancestors and keeping them as slaves.
Money. They walk inside THE MURAL ROOM. The crowd is yelling to a 'nay' vote for Mendoza on the television.
Loser! Margaret hurries to sit with a friend. Mallory hugs Leo at the door. The next vote is a 'yea.'
Not yet. Mallory was standing behind him, and pops him on the shoulder.
[spins around] It's my day of jubilee.
I despise you and everything you stand for.
All right, the day was a little bit better a few seconds ago, but that's all right.
How could you write that position paper?
No, honestly I am dumb. Most of the time I'm playing smart.
Mallory, you can't be thinking about ruining my day of jubilee by yelling at me about school vouchers.
I was strongly considering it, yes.
Sam. Toby. You're about to put a guy on the Supreme Court. The crowd is silent.
Yea. Massive cheering. Even Toby, who was holding a bottle of champagne in his lap, smiles and puts up his hands in victory.
Toby? How about now? Toby opens the bottle, the champagne foams up and all over his lap as he stands.

Scenes.Scene Heading: SMASH CUT TO: MAIN TITLES.
FADE IN: INT. THE MURAL ROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: THURSDAY, 11:30 P.M. After the celebration, Josh is sprawled on a chair by the fireplace. Donna is on the couch.

Dialogues.Line: I don't understand. Salvador Dali had distinctive penmanship?
Well, for one thing, he wrote in Spanish.
Which would account for his distinctive penmanship.
[walks up] Excuse me. Am I interrupting something important?
I can't even begin to tell you how you're not.
[giggles] [to Donna] Would you mind if I have a...
[gets up and picks up her shoes] I'll go see if people are having fun in the other room. [leaves]
Our nominee for Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights.
Stadler has a problem with him.
I mean... was there a thing? [stands]
Two sentences on the back dust jacket of a book that's coming out called The Unpaid Debt.
Cause of a thing he wrote on a dust cover?
I've been singing that song for the last three hours. So talk to him tomorrow, would you?
I'm not the guy for this.
Yeah, you are. We hear the crowd from the other room.
Oh, where she lip synchs to the thing?
Toby's better for this. Look at the job he did on the Mendoza confirmation.
Toby's barely alive as a result of the Mendoza confirmation. This one's you. Let's go watch 'The Jackal.' Leo walks, Josh follows into the HALLWAY.
I'm a white guy from Connecticut.
I'm saying, isn't this kind of a delicate subject for me to get into with a black civil rights lawyer from Athens, Georgia?
Then he's sure to love me.
Yeah. They meet up with Cathy, walking down the hall.
In his office, fighting with your daughter.
Tell him to come to the Press Room. He's not going to want to miss 'The Jackal.'

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. SAM'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Mallory and Sam are in his office and having a discussion.

Dialogues.Line: And your position is that school vouchers are a good idea?
How did you get this paper?
Your father gave you my position paper?
See. I think he's trying to drive a wedge between us.
I thought we had something going on, Sam.
And yet you haven't told me that you favor school vouchers?
I... first of all, hang on. We haven't been on a date yet.
And what kind of dates have you had that you're amazed this hasn't come up?
Seriously. The other guys. They order drinks and they say, "Before we go any further, I'd like you to know my position on school vouchers?"
Are you going to have a serious discussion with me about this?

No. Because you know why? Because I am off duty. Toby and I have spent the last three months putting a guy on the bench. The sun has set and I have earned my government salary and then some. I'm done working. And we haven't been out on a date and that's supposed to be tonight. Now we're going to go in there and watch C.J. do 'The Jackal.' And believe me, if you haven't seen C.J. do 'The Jackal,' then you haven't seen Shakespeare the way it was meant to be done. We're going to watch C.J. do 'The Jackal' and then we're going to get a late dinner, after which I may or may not kiss you good night. 'Cause there is something going on between us, Mallory. But frankly, I don't think you're doing a very good job on your part, so I've decided to take over.
I didn't think so, but you got to give me credit for trying.
Apparently you don't have to give me credit for trying.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. PRESS ROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: The crowd is thick to watch. Toby pushes a button on the radio. The jazz plays. Toby is smiling. C.J. is in the middle of the room, and the crowd encourages her to begin. C.J. pantomimes and lip synchs to 'The Jackal.'

Dialogues.Line: 'He was fat black cat cool like a Friday afternoon martini, chillin' at a quarter after five. Twist of lime. Coke on the side. The brother loved the high life. Had a PhD in Street Strife. They called him the Jackal... The Jackal.' The crowd loves it. The singer laughs, with a great deep voice. Josh claps and makes his way toward Toby, who's smoking a cigar.
There's a little speed bump with Jeff Breckenridge. Leo gave it to me because he thinks you're burned out after Mendoza. I said I thought that was ridiculous. What do you think?
[long pause] Are you talking to me... during 'The Jackal?'
I was just... Toby actually bops up and down! He is one giddy man, smiling, a giggle in his voice.
Never talk to me during 'The Jackal.'

'He was big Mack daddy super black stylin' a diamonds in the back Cadillac. Fur lined boards. White walled wheels. Cruise control. Built for speed. Chrome on everything. And the stereophonic speakers. But he really didn't need them. When they called him... The Jackal.' The crowd claps. Leo is watching with a smile on his face as Sam walks to him.
So Mallory read my position paper on school vouchers.
How do you suppose she got a hold of that?
Well, as it turns out, you gave it to her.
Hmmm. School vouchers is a serious subject with Mallory.
Yeah, thanks for the heads up.
I don't mind you dating my only daughter, but you can't expect me not to have some fun along the way.
Mallory and I haven't actually been on a date yet.
Well, you hang in there, son.

'Fly boy was in the buttermilk hard. Livin' fast. Livin' large. Six foot four and not an ounce of fat. When women ask, "Is you a proud cat?" He'd say, "Oh, dear. I'm more than that. I'm the roanest of the roan. And in case you hadn't known... They call me The Jackal. The Jackal... The Jackal.' The crowd applauds as the jazz fades.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. C.J.'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: C.J. is at her desk, humming, back to the door as Danny walks in. He sees her move her hips to a song.

Dialogues.Line: What are you doing here so late?
Congratulations on Mendoza, that's got to feel good.
It does. [takes a gulp of champagne]
So I'm home. By myself. Listening to my police scanner.
Danny, you were like, President of your high school audio-visual club, weren't you?
I was, in fact, not President of the AV Club. I was vice-President. Bobby Pfeiffer was President, and that's something I don't like to talk about.
Josh said to come by for a drink. C.J. puts on her scarf. She's going home.
You should have gotten here earlier.
I would have, except I was home listening to my police scanner.
David Arbor was arrested outside a frat party. He's going to be charged with felony possession and possible intent to distribute.
Is there any chance David Arbor is not the son of Bob Arbor?
There's not any chance of that. No. Plus one other thing...
Zoey was at the frat party.
Well, at least I know what I'll be doing when I come into work tomorrow. [starts to take off her coat]

Speaking of tomorrow, when you start handing out information, please remember I came down here at one in the morning to tell you this when there was no earthly reason that I had to, and also that you're secretly in love with me.
Make sure you remind my office.
You could do 'The Jackal' for me. Right here, right now. She flips his scarf over his shoulder and rubs his arm.
Okay. Danny exits. C.J. picks up the phone.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. HALLWAY - DAY
Scenes.Description: C.J. and Carol are walking and talking.

Dialogues.Line: Do this... I'm honestly not sure the President even knows.
I'm honestly not sure the President even knows.
Yeah, you know why? Because it's such a non-story it hasn't come up yet today. Say it now.
I'm honestly not sure the President even knows.
The kid's father's a major Democratic fundraiser.
And I'm sure the President would offer him his best wishes and support during what must be a troubling time.
The President's daughter was at a party where there was a drug bust. They go inside C.J.'S OFFICE.
Zoey left the party well before the incident.
Has the President had any reaction at all?
I'm honestly not sure the President even knows.
There it is. Carol leaves. Mandy comes from the other door.
Let's keep it that way. Mandy taps on Josh's open office door. She walks inside JOSH'S OFFICE. Josh is sitting with his feet on his desk.
Yeah, you didn't want to talk to me about banana bars by any chance, did you?
I think we should get a panda bear.
You say that now, but I'm the one who's going to end up feeding him and walking him.
You guys have gotten something more than 3000 letters in the last ten days, wanting to know when we're getting a new bear for the National Zoo?
What happened to the old bear?
Then what are you talking to me for?
Did I write any of them?
Who should I be talking to?
About getting a new panda bear?
Toby. You should be talking to Toby. Donna walks in with files. Lots of files, and sets them on the chair in front of Josh's desk. She hands him the top one.
Yeah. Toby can help you out.
I have to tell a black civil rights lawyer why I don't owe him any money.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. COLLEGE CAFETERIA - DAY
Scenes.Description: Zoey and her friends are practicing French at a table.

Dialogues.Line: Nous travaillons. Two agents, Mike and Gina, are around.
Have someone bring the car around back. Mike goes. Gina goes to Zoey's table where she's there with friends, one of which is STACY.
Are we doing French in Kelly's room tonight?
Okay. Zoey and Stacy start to leave.
Zoey. This way, we're going out back.
They're not supposed to come on campus.
[to Stacy] Can I ask you a question? What is up with Marjorie's hair?
Yes, I know! I didn't want to say anything back at the table. [They both giggle.]
[to Gina] Gina, listen to this... we've been falling asleep listening to our French tapes.
Are you ready? ZOEY and STACY Michelle, Anne, Vous travaillez? Ah. Non. Nous regardons le television. Porquois? They walk into the KITCHEN. Gina is ahead and a reporter, EDGAR DRUMM, runs in view.
Zoey! Gina knocks him back to the freezer.
I'm Special Agent Gina Toscano of the U.S. Secret Service, what's your name?
Edgar Drumm of the Charleston Citizen. I have a question for Miss Bartlet.
Yeah. Zoey. Gina turns around and Mike is there.
Mike, take her to the car.
Zoey, what do you think it says about the country that the President's daughter is partying with drug dealers?
What do you think it says about the country?
David Arbor isn't a drug dealer.
Yeah, why'd you go to the party, Zoey?
[was heading off, but spins around] I was invited. I didn't even know David Arbor was going to be there.
Guys! I want you in the car now. The girls and Mike walk to the car.
You're a real jackass, you know that? Drumm laughs. He got a quote. He takes out his notebook.
I have to say if this is how the Secret Service behaves in the Bartlet Administration, it's a sad state of affairs.
We're all going to have to learn to live with your disappointment. [smiles pleasantly and then heads off]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. COMMUNICATIONS OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Sam comes out of his office with papers. Cathy is at her desk.

Dialogues.Line: This draft is done. The office staff turns and applauds.
This draft is done, and it's done on schedule. On schedule is going to be my middle name from now on. Seriously. I'm having it legally changed.
[looks on Sam's appointment book] At noon you're on the Hill with Brennan and Landis, 3:00 with the East Asia team, 4:00 with Medicare, 4:30 with the President, 6:00 with the advance team.
The noon meeting with Brennan and Landis on the Hill?
Let's see if we can cancel it.
That's not a good enough reason.
I really don't want to go.
And you've got Mallory at eleven.
You've got Mallory at eleven. Right now.
What do you mean I've got Mallory?
[appears] I decided to see you during your business hours.
I didn't want to take advantage of the fact that we're dating.
That's kinda sad for you, isn't it?
Well, isn't that adorable? Come in. Mallory goes into his office. Ssam looks in disbelief at Cathy, then goes in and shuts the door.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. JOSH'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Donna goes to announce his appointment.

Dialogues.Line: Mr. Breckenridge? Josh straightens his desk, then JEFF BRECKENRIDGE comes in.
Jeff Breckenridge. They shake hands. Josh motions for him to sit.
Good to meet you. Help yourself to a chair. Can Donna get you anything?
You were a second year summer intern at Debevoise and Plimpton when my father was a partner there. [sits]
Your father was a partner at Debevoise and Plimpton?
I met him. He's a wonderful man. How is he?
The night of the Illinois primary.
Thanks. Listen. I just got this handed to me last night, so I'm not as up to speed as I'd like.
A couple of Republicans on the Judiciary Committee have a problem with me.
Any specific problem or they just don't like me on spec?
No. [laughs a little] There's a book coming out by Otis Hastings called The Unpaid Debt. Hastings' position is that African Americans are owed monetary reparations for slavery.
You're quoted on the back jacket.
Yes. JOSH looks at the book on his desk.
You wrote, "Otis Hastings is a unique and extraordinary historian. This book should be read by everyone and burned into the minds of white America."
Just to start, you weren't misquoted... right?
Okay. And I'm assuming that if asked by the Committee, you'll say that you favor reparations?

If asked, I'll tell the Committee that my father's fathers were kidnapped outside a village called Wimbabwa, brought to New Guinea, sold to a slave trader from Boston and bought by a plantation owner in Wadsworth, South Carolina, where they worked... for no wages.
And you're looking for back pay?
Just out of curiosity... did you have a figure in mind?

Dr. Harold Washington, who's chief economist at the Manchester Institute, calculated the number of slaves held, multiplied it by the number of hours worked, multiplied that by the market value of manual labor and came up with a very conservative figure.
1.7 trillion dollars. Josh was taking a sip of coffee that he's now having a hard time swallowing.
Okay. Listen, this is probably a better discussion to have in the abstract, don't you think?
I mean someone owes me and my friends 1.7 trillion dollars.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. C.J.'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: C.J.'s working on the laptop on her desk and there's a knock on the door.

Dialogues.Line: [enters] Charlie's here. She opens the door further and we see Charlie in the hall. He walks in.
Yes indeed. Charlie, Charlie, Charlie, Chaz.
I hear you burned the place down last night.
I can bring it. What's up?
She had a little run-in on campus with a reporter named Edgar Drumm who writes for a newspaper called the Charleston Citizen.
Edgar Drumm isn't a reporter. He's a professional Bartlet baiter, and the Charleston Citizen isn't a newspaper, it's fund-raising newsletter for the radical right. What'd he ask her?
He asked her if the President's daughter should be partying with drug dealers.

Gina put her in the car. The thing she wanted me to ask you about was this... David Arbor's a good friend and she really loves him a lot and he's not a drug dealer and she wanted to see what you could do about nipping that in the bud.
I can talk to a couple of people.

The guy doesn't sell drugs. He just buys them, takes them and gets unconscious. Zoey and her friends are trying to help him. In fact, Zoey was bringing him back the car keys she confiscated from him last week.
Tell Danny I'm coming to see him.
I drove my boyfriend's Porsche once.
Yeah. Charlie leaves, and C.J. goes back to typing.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. NORTHWEST LOBBY - DAY
Scenes.Description: Toby walks down the hall, meets up with Margaret.

Dialogues.Line: Yeah. Why wouldn't I be okay?
You don't usually say, "Hey there, Margaret."
You, on the other hand, should turn that frown upside down.
Let your smile be your umbrella, Margaret.
Okay, now you're scaring the crap out of me, Toby. Margaret walks off. Toby walks and sings.
[singing] Gray skies are going to clear up... Hi Bobby. Put on a happy face. Hi Janet. A lot of people in the hallway are confused by him.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. SAM'S OFFICE  - DAY
Scenes.Description: Mallory and Sam are in the middle of a deep discussion.

Dialogues.Line: Tax dollars should go to public schools, not aiding the shipment of students to private schools, many of which are religious. And by the way, I don't know how you're getting around the separation of Church and State on that one.
We have people on the payroll who are experts at obfuscating the Constitution.
Oh, yes. [pulls out her list from his position paper]
We've been here for an hour, Mallory.
School vouchers provide help for only a few students.
We're offering a solution for that.
You're offering a lifeboat to the select few for whom vouchers will make any kind of difference.
Mallory, everything that you're saying makes sense. I just think that the state of urban schools is such that if you can save even one kid...
[stands] You can save more than one kid.
By asking Congress to approve, not just a little, but a lot more money for public education. Sam laughs.

[stands] Public education has been a public policy disaster for 40 years. Having spent around four trillion dollars on public schools since 1965, the result has been a steady and inexorable decline in every measurable standard of student performance, to say nothing of health and safety. But don't worry about it, because the U.S. House of Representatives is on the case. I feel better already.
For a guy who's trying to date me, that was pretty snotty.
Well, hang on. These are office hours. If I'd know I was working on that I would have had a whole different attitude.
The meeting on the Hill. I'd love to keep talking, Mal, but I have this meeting on the Hill.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. PRESS ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: Danny is typing at his desk. C.J. walks to him.

Dialogues.Line: You hear anything about Edgar Drumm talking to Zoey?
You know what you never do?
You never tell me you like my suspenders.
He asked her if the President's daughter should be partying with drug dealers.
That's what I heard. [gets up to walk away]
She said she didn't know Arbor was going to be there.
It's Edgar Drumm, C.J. No one...
Nothing. Those really are nice suspenders. C.J. leaves.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. JOSH'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Josh and Jeff are still in their meeting.

Dialogues.Line: What? [sits back at his desk with another cup of coffee]

I'm saying slavery reparations aren't anything new. January 16th, 1865, General Sherman issued Special Field Order Number 15. Nearly a half million acres from South Carolina to Florida were divided up into 40 acre plots and given to newly freed slaves. He also granted them the use of various decommissioned army supplies including...

Yes. But the order was rescinded four years later by Andrew Johnson. In the '60s, during the Newark riots, you could hear the looters shouting, "That was my 40 acres, I'll be back for the mule." [drinks coffee]
See, if you guys had just paid up on time...
A lesson well learned. But let's talk about your confirmation.
And while we're on the subject of the Civil War, let's remember the 600,000 white men who died over the issue of slavery.
It's why a lot of them died, Jeff. And there's no other place and time in recorded history where an event like that has occurred. So... let's... leave it at that and move on.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. COMMUNICATIONS OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Toby is still happy and passes by. Mandy calls him from inside.

Dialogues.Line: Madeline, you are charming and you are brilliant and for you, I have all the time in the world.
It's the day after his Day of Jubilee.
We've never seen him sustain a good mood this long.
Bonnie, you are dedicated and you are beautiful. And Ginger, you are other nice things.
You bet. She pushes him into TOBY'S OFFICE. Toby sets his stuff down on the desk.

Mandy, I feel like I've lost a hundred and eighty pounds. I'm smiling. I'm laughing. I'm enjoying the people I work with. I gotta snap out of this. [clears off his leather chair to take a seat] What's on your mind?
I want you to help me get the Chinese to give us a new panda bear to replace Lum-Lum.
[long pause] Well, that did the trick.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - DAY
Scenes.Description: Zoey enters through a door and walks down the hall. She sees Charlie.

Dialogues.Line: Hey, what are you doing here?
I talked to her, by the way.
She's said she was going to talk to Danny.
You could have kissed me hello, you know.
That's what your dorm room is for.
You'd better believe it. When I kiss you, I want a good two miles between your mouth and the Oval Office.
Stacy tells me you're afraid to show me affection in public.
Tell Stacy to meet me in the middle of Union Station and we'll see how it goes.
Hey Charlie? Does C.J. have a problem?
I wonder what she wants to see me about then?
I'm not afraid of being affectionate in public. Zoey pushes him against the wall and kisses him deeply. He very much responds. Zoey walks away, as Charlie smiles.
See? Down the hall, Carol greets her.
Hi, Zoey. I'll get her. Carol knocks and pokes her head in C.J.'S OFFICE.
Hey, Zoey, thanks for stopping by. Carol, can you get the door?
Sure. C.J. walks to the couch as Carol exits and closes the door. Zoey joins C.J. on the couch.
So I'm assuming you heard I talked to a guy.
Yeah. I know I'm supposed to just walk away, but...
But he pushed your buttons a little.
Did you tell him that you didn't know that David Arbor was going to be at the party?
Okay... Zoey, I need to know why you lied to him.
And I need to know why you're lying to me right now.
If you didn't know he was going to be there, why'd you have his car keys with you? Zoey doesn't answer.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. SECRET SERVICE CONFERENCE ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: Banks of computers and monitors, televisions, and security cameras are around. Agents are seated in chairs facing the fronts as Ron Butterfield is heading the meeting.

Dialogues.Line: ...And Mr. Kleeg is being detained for questioning by field agents in Albuquerque. Mr. Derrick Horgiboum. Mr. Horgiboum threatened to blow up the Smithsonian unless Zoey Bartlet agreed to meet with him for a drink. Mr. Horgiboum is in custody. And the Smithsonian remains open for business. Kelly? You had something?
The newest sorority pledge stunt is get your picture taken with Zoey.
Here's hoping our biggest threat is from the girls of Kappa Kappa Gamma. Some laugh.
It's not. We're adding some hate groups to the list. The Aryan White Resistance, The Christian Defense League, The World Church of the Creator, and Central New York White Pride.
The Office of Protective Research says the most recent letters have been signed off with the slogan, '14 words'.
Who can tell me what 14 words stands for?
[raises her hand] We must secure the existence of white people and the future for white children.
That's right. What else do you have, Gina?

Two death threats were received earlier in the week. One against Zoey, one against Charlie. They were made with letters cut from a magazine. And the OPR has identified the paper and the typeset as Resistance Magazine.
This magazine is geared towards recruiting younger people.
That's right sir. And the letters have repeatedly used the phrase, "Following the voice of blood".
It's the title of the first record by a band called Graceland. They're very popular amongst skinheads. Sir, I'm fairly convinced we're looking for two 15-year-old boys.
I think you're right. Everyone hit the pictures and see if anyone looks familiar from the rope line. Remember it could be anyone. Thank you. They all get up. A guy comes up to Gina.
C.J. Cregg is outside. She'd like to step in.
They told me you were having a briefing. I didn't want to intrude.
I'm fine. I just needed to talk to you about the party last night.
Could you describe what, if any, contact Zoey might have had with David Arbor last night?
I'm not permitted to discuss the behavior of my protectee.
I'm trying to straighten out a discrepancy with what she told me.
Gina, I'm the press secretary. There's a story that Zoey's involved with, and I need you to tell me what you know about last night.
I'm sorry, C.J. I can't protect her if she feels she has to do things behind my back. I'm not permitted to discuss the behavior of the protectee.
C.J., the thing with the reporter this morning... it was fast, it was physical. She's 19 years old and she thought her father was in trouble.
Okay. Thanks. I appreciate it. Sorry about the...
[sits at her desk] Are you sure you don't want to stay and have some coffee? I'm going to stay and look through an FBI photo album of teenage Nazis.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. SAM'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Sam and Mallory are still at it. Only now, they've taken off their suit coats.

Dialogues.Line: It occurs to me Mallory, that you attended a private primary school, a private high school and a private college.

Well, just that liberals have no problem with rich kids going to expensive private schools, that doesn't undermine public education. And liberals have no problem with middle-class kids going to parochial schools, that doesn't undermine public education.

The idea that letting poor public school students choose private alternatives would destroy public education is simply contrary to our experience. Boston Latin, the oldest public school in America, is still the best secondary school in New England.
Great, but they're not all Boston Latin and Bronx Science, Sam. And since when are the liberals the other guys in conversations you have? There's a knock on the door. C.J. pops in.
Absolutely. [to Mallory] Excuse me. SAM goes out into the COMMUNICATIONS OFFICE.
Edgar Drumm ambushed Zoey when she was coming out of lunch.
Yeah. She said she didn't know David Arbor was going to be there when she did know David Arbor was going to be there.
Spend all day surrounded by reporters? It starts to become instinct.
It doesn't sound too bad. Let's just make sure the President doesn't get involved.
Yeah... well... when he hears someone tried to talk to her on campus...
You're going to have to sit on it.
I'm not going to be able to.
C.J., you can't back down in front of him. You got to get in his face.
Okay. [turns to others] Does anyone else have any advice... that could... uh...
C.J., listen to me. It's your job. It's what he needs you to do.
I would like to see Mallory socially... C.J. looks into Sam's office and smiles at Mallory.
But I can't seem to get her past this fight that we're having. C.J. turns her body so Mallory can't see either of them and picks up a pencil from a desk.
Tell her you want to continue the fight over lunch.
Yeah. It's certainly better advice than "get in the President's face."
I'm going to go back into my office.
Cool. I'm going to go check the want ads.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. TOBY'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Toby is about at the end of his patience.

Dialogues.Line: A panda bear to replace Dim Sum?
Hsing-Hsing. That was his name. Hsing-Hsing. Yeah. Hsing-Hsing was given to us as a gift by the Chinese government when Nixon...
Then Hsing-Hsing got lonely, so the Chinese sent a mate over, I think, it's name was Ping.
Whatever. Ping, or Ling, dies. Hsing-Hsing mourns. Panda bears, it turns out, mourn. And for Hsing-Hsing, it seemed like the time was unendurable.
I know exactly how he felt.
Anyway... as you know, Hsing-Hsing succumbed to liver disease and passed away earlier this year.
And I was thinking that it would be a good idea as a symbol to signal how serious we are about our relationship with China, if... we asked them for another bear.
I think it would be a good idea, as a symbol... to signal that China is serious about their relationship with us, if they stopped running over their citizens with tanks.
Mandy! Call the embassy and have them send us over a damn bear. What's the problem?
First of all, pandas are very rare. There are maybe a thousand of them and they're only in China.
Because the other one will get lonely.
The other one will get lonely. Well then have them send us two.
And second of all, China's not inclined to give us gifts right now.
Then get us two regular bears, a bucket of black paint, a bucket of white paint, bam, bam, next case.
It's hard to believe that the wildlife lobby was nervous about you.
Mandy! They stare at each other.
What made you think I'd be interested in this?
Josh said you were my man.
[thinks it over] Oh... I have to say, Mandy... I'm impressed with how much you've grown.
Well, there was a time if you got played by Josh like this, you'd want to get back at him right away, and it's good to see you rise above that.
He used you to have a little fun with me 'cause he has to deal with Breckenridge on slavery reparations.
Yeah, but it's good to see you get past that.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Leo is on the phone when Mallory and Sam come in.

Dialogues.Line: [barrels on anyway] Dad, I'm sorry, but Sam's asked me to have lunch with him and I need your permission. Leo tells his call to hang on and puts the phone down.
What do you need my permission to have lunch for?
She says she always asks her father's permission before she has lunch with fascists.
He's in favor of school vouchers, Dad.
When we're gearing up for a debate, we have the smart guys take the other side.
[to Sam] You stood there and argued with me.
Would the two of you take it outside?
I thought you were trying to drive a wedge between us.
Yeah, but now you're just boring the crap out of me.

Mallory, education is the silver bullet. Education is everything. We don't need little changes. We need gigantic monumental changes. Schools should be palaces. The competition for the best teachers should be fierce. They should be making six-figure salaries. School should be incredibly expensive for government and absolutely free of charge to its citizens, just like national defense. That's my position. I just haven't figured out how to do it yet.
[softened] You stood there and argued with me.
And we can continue the argument. But it's lunchtime now. We're going to have lunch.
Yes, you may go have lunch with the fascist.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE OVAL OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Bartlet is laying on one of the couches reading. Charlie comes in.

Dialogues.Line: Sir, you know your lunch with Mr. Girardi got canceled.
I heard. It's the first time anyone's canceled lunch on me since I took office.
I'm sure Mr. Girardi meant no offense, sir. He was taken to the hospital with pneumonia.
I'm not saying he didn't have a good excuse.
Rules of Civility and Decent Behavior in Company and Conversation by George Washington.

The rules were drawn from an English translation of a French book of maxims. Washington copied them down when he was 14 years old. [reads] "When you sit down, keep your feet firm and even, without putting one on the other or crossing them. Put not off your clothes in the presence of others, nor go out of your chamber half-dressed." What a tightassed little priss he must've been.
[takes off her glasses and regards Charlie] Do you think I could take George Washington?
Could you have taken George Washington in a war?
Well, you'd have the Air Force and he'd have the Minutemen, right?
Still, I think you could probably take him.
Yeah. [winks and puts his glasses back on to read]
You can send her in. Charlie leaves and C.J. comes in.
[reads] "When in company, put not your hands on any part of your body not usually covered."
Well... I do what it takes to keep the press corps happy, Mr. President. Bartlet puts the book on the coffee table and sits up. C.J. sits on the couch opposite the table.
Yeah, you're right. What's going on?
Don't blow your stack, all right?
She was asked should the President's daughter be partying with drug dealers and she said she didn't know David Arbor was going to be at the party. Except she did know.
'Cause sometimes 19 year-old girls lie when they don't have to.
Mr. President... give her a break. This thing's happened to her friend, she doesn't know how it affects her father. Edgar Drumm is shouting at her while she comes out of class. She choked.
[gets riled] A reporter talked to her on campus?
[starts to put on his shoes] Put the press in the briefing room. Tell them I'm coming right over.
We have been over this and we have been over this and we have been over this! They are not supposed to talk to my daughter on campus.
I don't give a damn if it was the Bergen County Shopper's Guide. I want to talk to the press.
You can't talk to the press!

I'm telling you now, Mr. President, this isn't about your daughter! It's about the first daughter and that's my job and you're not going down there! You, me, Charlie and Zoey are the only four people who know she was lying and there's no reason it doesn't need to stay that way. It's a non-story. You go down there and it's a big story! Bartlet has his hand on the doorknob and takes a breath. Then turns around.
So I just sit in my office and fume?
Yes. And if anybody asks you, you haven't heard anything about it.
Did you know he jumped out at Zoey? Gina Toscano put him into a wall?
I haven't heard anything about it.
I could take George Washington, by the way.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. JOSH'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Jeff and Josh are still in the meeting. Jeff is pacing, Josh is sitting with his feet on his desk.

Dialogues.Line: I knew you were going to bring up the Japanese.
We gave 1.2 billion to Japanese-Americans who were in internment camps.
They were actually in internment camps. Bring me a living slave and then you've got a case.
I think I've got a case without the living slave, but I'm just a civil rights expert, so what do I know?
Jeff, the committee is going to be looking for a certain degree of practicality. We don't have $1.7 trillion. To raise $1.7 trillion, we would have to sell Texas and the U.S. Navy.
I understand the predicament and I'm willing to give you a break. We'll take our money in tax deductions and scholarship funds, how 'bout that?
How about you take it in affirmative action and empowerment zones and civil rights acts?
Three things which we wouldn't have needed in the first place.

[stands, getting ticked] You know, Jeff... I'd love to give you the money, I really would. But I'm a little short of cash right now. It seems the S.S. officer forgot to give my grandfather his wallet back when he let him out of Birkenau.
Well, your beef's with the Germans.
You're damn right it is! Josh pauses and looks at his father's picture in the wall.
What the hell are we talking about? He sits back down again. So does Jeff.

We have laws in this country. You break them, you pay your fine. You break God's laws, that's a different story. You can't kidnap a civilization and sell them into slavery. No amount of money will make up for it, and all you have to do is look, 200 years later, at race relations in this country.
No amount of money will make up for it.
Take it out. Look at the back. Josh does.

The seal, the pyramid, it's unfinished. With the eye of God looking over it. And the words Annuit Coeptis. He, God, Favors our Undertaking. The seal is meant to be unfinished, because this country's meant to be unfinished. We're meant to keep doing better. We're meant to keep discussing and debating and we're meant to read books by great historical scholars and then talk about them, which is why I lent my name to a dust cover. I want to be your Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights. I'll do an outstanding job for all people in this country. You got any problem with me saying all that to the committee?
Yeah. They put on their coats.
There's going to be a lot of these meetings before your confirmation. Why don't you let me get lunch this time, you get it next time?
Hey Suzanne. Josh and Jeff walk out the door.

Scenes.Scene Heading: DISSOLVE TO: END CREDITS.
